posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
campgod wrote:
 My thought was to wear down my opponent then blast him with a Hellball to knock him down then DA him to the grave. Not sure if this is feasible or not.

 
The words "wear down" and "blast" are not in the vocabulary of an assassin. "Death attack" and "grave" are. The death attack is a surprise attack that sends the target to his grave before he realizes what is happening.
In order to get the best possible death attack, you want to take as many assassin levels as possible, and then some. A high intelligence helps to some extent with the DC too.
If you want to take enough caster/PM levels to be able to cast epic spells, that will subtract a lot from the efficiency of the death attack, both damage and DC. A hellball is a one shot trick that is far less effective than a maximized death attack.
For further reading: See my assassin guide under the "game guides" forum.

posts.author: MrZork
posts.content:
Campgod, just to expand a bit on what others are noting: Hellball is a marginal epic spell for assassins, and perhaps even in general. For purposes of generating KD, any one shot attack that only KDs the target for 3 seconds isn't worth an epic feat. And, even for other purposes, unless your PW modifies the spell substantially, Hellball has pretty major drawbacks. For one, it's a non-party-friendly spell with a 20 meter range and 20 meter radius, so it's pretty easy to get caught in the spell yourself (especially if you have any hope of dashing in to get death attacks on the target when they are KDed) and it's especially hard on summons. Second, any substantial elemental resistance can really nerf the damage output. Even plain old Protection from Elements will cut the average damage to the target to 20 hp total, and that's if he fails his reflex save.

Anyway, if generating KDs via spells is the goal, Bigby's is a better route. Of course, if BFH is nerfed (as it is on Sinfar), then you are stuck against anyone who can make a reflex save. Same reflex save issue for Great Thunderclap (reflex save and also short duration), though at least that spell ignores spell resistance, which can be useful.

If you are looking to incorporate epic spells into your build, it looks like Sinfar has buffed up the two summons a bit. And, this is sort of a roundabout way of getting KD out of your epic spell, since the Dragon Knight dragon has IKD and can often KD opponents with high discipline (the dragon class is full AB, dragons typically have high STR, and they get a +8 size bonus on the discipline check). DK is also a nice summons against opponents who are sneakers, since they have permanent True Sight. The typical (and legitimate) complaint about Dragon Knight is the relatively short duration, but it should be long enough for PvP, especially since Sinfar DKs are immune to Word of Faith.

Val, nice build. BTW, it doesn't affect the outcome (or reduce the value of using bard as the base class), but assassins get UMD as a skill, so he would have that even with wizard as his base class.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
@ Campgod, i wouldn't be so hasty to throw out the Disarm feats yet, you see those are one of the little nasty secrets of this build, and they go nicely with the 2-Handed aspect of your Assassin. Basically whenever you make a disarm attempt with your Scythe against any opponents that wields tiny weapons (kukris, daggers) you will gain an intimidating (+8) AB, this goes on for small weapons (handaxes, short-swords) as well but to a lesser degree-the bonus is only (+4) AB, and when you fight someone who uses medium weapons (longswords, warhammers) you simply make the disarm attempt for free. Now i will make a guess that if they fail even a single Disarm check they will lose the match, (unless they hit really hard with their bear fists) and the same goes for Death attack of course, so use it and use it a lot! There are two exceptions to this rule, don't use it against other 2-Handers and don't use it against Open Fist Monks. You don't often see people use this feat, because many opponents in PvE have non-disarmable weapons for balance reasons and of course monsters usually don't have any weapons other than their natural ones, but in PvP this is very useful as all of your opponents who bear a weapon are eligible targets for this feat. If you still don't find that feat useful then replace it with anything that you deem useful in your server.

@ Dark Knight, you may find useful the SF: Conjuration feats pre-epic (perhaps in place of the disarm/ improve disarm feats) for your build, as they give several bonuses to the epic summons in Sinfar, and thanks :)
Ah, almost forgot that Sinfar Pale masters of 11 level and above, when they cast " Dragon Knight " they instead summon a Dracolich! Now, i don't know if this affects the stats of the dragon at all but it is damn cool!

@ Zork, thanks for the heads-up man - i forgot that Assassins have UMD in their skill list as well.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
@ Dark Knight, the PM AC bonuses are not negated completely but instead halfed from my understanding of the rules changes. For example 16 PM levels in Sinfar would get you (+5) Bone armor instead of (+10) which is the norm. Also EMA does not give you (+5) Dodge AC but (+4) instead and EW is (level * 20) damage absorbion instead of (level * 50) and those changes i presume is to prevent the PM domination in the PvP arena. Still though even with those changes PM's are incredibly hard to defeat especially with (16) levels of them and the two defensive epic spells considering that they will have (+9) AC above the norm and a (320) damage shield that you will have to burst before even you start hacking at their real life points. Don't forget that they are immune to both Criticals and Sneaks so all hits are just normal hits. Equally attractive though is the dual epic summons though both because they have strengthen them and because they will make your opponents susceptible to your sneak attacks. In both cases though i would say go for a Strength Assassin because if you have only (19) Assassin levels you can't solely rely on your Death attacks.

Sinfar Rule Changes => http://forum.sinfar.net/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=682

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: The first assassin build demonstrates how a single level of PM can be used to qualify early for assassin since PM doesn't have to cross class the stealth skills. At the same time PM adds to wizard spell-slots so you can learn lvl 3 spells with 4 levels of wizard and one level of PM. It is a bit unusual to take less than 10 levels of PM (which gives the crit immunity), but the class skill selection can sometimes be a reason to do just that.
